name: Families and Schools Together (FAST)
summary: An evidence-based, multi-family group program designed to strengthen family functioning and improve children's behavior and academic performance by building collaboration between families, schools, and communities.
description: Families and Schools Together (FAST) is a structured, evidence-based, multi-family intervention aimed at preventing school failure, substance abuse, juvenile delinquency, and child abuse. The program brings together parents, children, teachers, and community members in weekly sessions that combine family-strengthening activities, parent empowerment, social support, and school engagement. FAST emphasizes building protective factors in children through enhanced family functioning, improved parent–child relationships, and stronger school–family connections. It is often implemented in schools, community centers, or social service agencies.

off_label_uses: Prevention of substance use in adolescents
Support for immigrant and refugee families
contraindications: Families unable to commit to group participation
Severe untreated psychiatric conditions requiring individualized care
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe, supportive, and community-based with no known risks.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: High—multiple randomized controlled trials support its effectiveness.
clinical_metadata.research_support: FAST has been implemented in over 25 countries and is backed by decades of research showing reductions in problem behaviors, improved academic outcomes, and stronger family-school bonds.

sections.text: FAST works by enhancing protective factors across family, school, and community systems. It builds family cohesion through shared activities, empowers parents as leaders, increases social support networks, and strengthens bonds between schools and families. These combined effects reduce child risk factors while promoting resilience and academic success.

sections.preparation: Schools and community organizations recruit families and form multi-family groups.
procedure: Structured family activities to strengthen relationships.
Parent empowerment sessions to build confidence and leadership.
Collaborative activities between families and school staff.
Peer support and social networking among families.

sections.pre_session: Families gather, check-in, and review the session plan.
sections.treatment_phase: Engage in structured family, parent, and community-building activities.
sections.post_session: Reflection, goal-setting, and social time to reinforce community ties.

long_term: Reduced substance use and delinquency risks

rare: Withdrawal if families feel uncomfortable in group setting

absolute: Families unwilling to participate in group settings
relative: Severe psychiatric or safety concerns requiring specialized care

ideal_candidates: Families with children at risk of behavioral or academic difficulties
Parents seeking greater connection with their child’s school
Communities aiming to strengthen family-school partnerships

facility: Schools, community centers, or partner agencies

studies: Kratochwill TR, et al. (2004). Families and Schools Together: An experimental analysis of a parent-mediated multi-family group program.
McDonald L, et al. (2006). Evaluation of FAST across multiple communities.
sections.limitations: Program effectiveness may vary depending on cultural context, fidelity of implementation, and family engagement levels.

sections.typical_session_cost: Program-based (funded by schools or community grants)
sections.insurance_coverage: Typically not billed through insurance; funded through schools, nonprofits, or public health agencies
sections.cost_effectiveness: High—prevents costly long-term academic and behavioral interventions.

sections.children: Core target population (K–8 students and families).
sections.immigrant-families: Adapted versions support language and cultural needs.

items: Widely recognized as a best-practice family strengthening program.
Can be scaled for large school districts or small community groups.
Cultural adaptations have been successful across diverse populations.
